articles.headline: India Backs Foreign Investment in Retailing
articles.snippet: The government of Manmohan Singh, which is facing political troubles, gave backing to measures that could open the country’s retail sector to global behemoths like Wal-Mart and Ikea.
articles.abstract: The government of Manmohan Singh, which is facing political troubles, gave backing to measures that could open the country’s retail sector to global behemoths like Wal-Mart and Ikea.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — After years of intense debate, India’s government agreed on Friday to open the country’s retail sector to global behemoths like Wal-Mart and Ikea, pushing for a profound shift in India’s economic and political direction.

articles.headline: Answering Questions on Student Loan Rates and the Murky Future
articles.snippet: Paying for college can be one of a household’s most complex financial decisions. Here, we try to supply answers to four of the most important questions on rates and avoiding financial surprises.
articles.abstract: Paying for college can be one of a household’s most complex financial decisions. Here, we try to supply answers to four of the most important questions on rates and avoiding financial surprises.
articles.lead_paragraph: Figuring out how to pay for college has quickly turned into one of life’s most complicated financial decisions.

articles.headline: Poll Finds Obama Is Erasing Romney’s Edge on Economy
articles.snippet: President Obama has taken away Mitt Romney’s advantage as the candidate voters say is most likely to restore the economy, according to the latest poll by The New York Times and CBS News.
articles.abstract: President Obama has taken away Mitt Romney’s advantage as the candidate voters say is most likely to restore the economy, according to the latest poll by The New York Times and CBS News.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama has taken away Mitt Romney’s longstanding advantage as the candidate voters say is most likely to restore the economy and create jobs, according to the latest poll by The New York Times and CBS News, which found a modest sense of optimism among Americans that White House policies are working.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Megan Thee-Brenan

articles.headline: Fed Responds to a Grim Reality
articles.snippet: In a meaningful departure from past policy, the Federal Reserve said it would focus on reducing unemployment at the risk of provoking higher inflation.
articles.abstract: In a meaningful departure from past policy, the Federal Reserve said it would focus on reducing unemployment at the risk of provoking higher inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Federal Reserve’s vice chairman said in a 1994 speech that the central bank “had a role in reducing unemployment,” colleagues were publicly dismissive. The very word “employment” did not appear in a policy statement until 2008. The Fed was focused on inflation, officials said time and again.

articles.headline: American Retailers Face Challenges in Expanding to Canada
articles.snippet: American retailers extending their reach northward may seem like an obvious move, but until recently, the Canadian market was hard to crack.
articles.abstract: American retailers extending their reach northward may seem like an obvious move, but until recently, the Canadian market was hard to crack.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Nordstrom and Target are about to open stores in Canada, J. Crew and Tory Burch just did so, and Ann Taylor and Kate Spade are scouting locations.
articles.byline: By Ian Austen and Stephanie Clifford

articles.headline: Money-Laundering Inquiry Is Said to Aim at U.S. Banks
articles.snippet: Regulators, led by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, are said to be close to taking action against JPMorgan Chase for insufficient safeguards.
articles.abstract: Regulators, led by the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, are said to be close to taking action against JPMorgan Chase for insufficient safeguards.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal and state authorities are investigating a handful of major American banks for failing to monitor cash transactions in and out of their branches, a lapse that may have enabled drug dealers and terrorists to launder tainted money, according to officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Lia Lee Dies; Life Went On Around Her, Redefining Care
articles.snippet: The story of Lia Lee, the severely brain-damaged daughter of Hmong refugees, inspired a book that affected the way American medicine is practiced across cultures.
articles.abstract: The story of Lia Lee, the severely brain-damaged daughter of Hmong refugees, inspired a book that affected the way American medicine is practiced across cultures.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1988, when Anne Fadiman met Lia Lee, then 5, for the first time, she wrote down her impressions in four spare lines that now read like found poetry:

articles.headline: U.S. Is Preparing for a Long Siege of Arab Unrest
articles.snippet: The White House is girding itself for an extended period of turmoil that will test the security of American diplomatic missions and President Obama’s ability to shape the forces of change in the Arab world.
articles.abstract: The White House is girding itself for an extended period of turmoil that will test the security of American diplomatic missions and President Obama’s ability to shape the forces of change in the Arab world.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After days of anti-American violence across the Muslim world, the White House is girding itself for an extended period of turmoil that will test the security of American diplomatic missions and President Obama’s ability to shape the forces of change in the Middle East.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Mark Landler

articles.headline: A U.S. Envoy Who Plunged Into Arab Life
articles.snippet: J. Christopher Stevens, who was killed at a diplomatic mission in Libya, had an affection for Arab culture and street life that made him many friends and contacts.
articles.abstract: J. Christopher Stevens, who was killed at a diplomatic mission in Libya, had an affection for Arab culture and street life that made him many friends and contacts.
articles.lead_paragraph: J. Christopher Stevens, the American ambassador to Libya who was killed in an assault on a diplomatic mission there last week, was happy to gossip, but was revered for listening. A northern Californian with a toothy grin, he had a passion for the Arab world and its language, and he went out of his way to use it, whether with officials or shopkeepers, in an effort to show respect.

articles.headline: Forgoing College to Pursue Dreams
articles.snippet: Thiel Fellowships pay young people to forgo college and to plunge into real-world projects. So what has become of those who managed to snag fellowships?
articles.abstract: Thiel Fellowships pay young people to forgo college and to plunge into real-world projects. So what has become of those who managed to snag fellowships?
articles.lead_paragraph: EDEN FULL should be back at Princeton by now. She should be hustling to class, hitting the books, acing tests. In short, she should be climbing that old-school ladder toward a coveted spot among America’s future elite.

articles.headline: A Condo Was Sold, Until It Wasn’t
articles.snippet: The odyssey of the short sale of a Florida condominium is another example of dysfunction in the mortgage market.
articles.abstract: The odyssey of the short sale of a Florida condominium is another example of dysfunction in the mortgage market.
articles.lead_paragraph: HORROR stories abound across Foreclosure Nation. But once in a while, a new one comes along to remind us just how dysfunctional our mortgage market is.

articles.headline: Mining the Power (and the Profit) of Conversation
articles.snippet: The Van Heyst Group helps companies organize live events and translate them into print, video and Web products.
articles.abstract: The Van Heyst Group helps companies organize live events and translate them into print, video and Web products.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEFORE there were TED Talks, there were Della talks.

articles.headline: In Prosecutors, Debt Collectors Find a Partner
articles.snippet: In exchange for a fee, district attorneys’ offices have been allowing debt collectors to use their letterhead when going after people behind on their bills.
articles.abstract: In exchange for a fee, district attorneys’ offices have been allowing debt collectors to use their letterhead when going after people behind on their bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: The letters are sent by the thousands to people across the country who have written bad checks, threatening them with jail if they do not pay up.

articles.headline: Challenged on Medicare, G.O.P. Loses Ground
articles.snippet: President Obama and his campaign are arguing that the Romney-Ryan approach to Medicare would leave older Americans vulnerable to rising health care costs.
articles.abstract: President Obama and his campaign are arguing that the Romney-Ryan approach to Medicare would leave older Americans vulnerable to rising health care costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Maria Rubin is one of the coveted independent voters in this swing state — so independent that she will not say whether she is voting for President Obama or Mitt Romney. She does share her age (63) and, more quickly, her opinion on Medicare: “I’m not in favor of changing it, or eliminating it.”

articles.headline: Audacious Raid on NATO Base Shows Taliban’s Reach
articles.snippet: The assault late Friday on one of the best-defended posts in Afghanistan was troubling because the attackers were able to penetrate the base, killing two and causing more than $200 million in damage.
articles.abstract: The assault late Friday on one of the best-defended posts in Afghanistan was troubling because the attackers were able to penetrate the base, killing two and causing more than $200 million in damage.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — An audacious Taliban attack on a heavily fortified base in southern Afghanistan did far more damage than initially reported, destroying or severely damaging eight attack jets in the most destructive single strike on Western matériel in the 11-year war, military officials said Sunday.

articles.headline: No Easy Answers on How to Fix the Banks in Europe
articles.snippet: Disagreements between finance ministers left open the question of how long Spain could go without outside financial assistance.
articles.abstract: Disagreements between finance ministers left open the question of how long Spain could go without outside financial assistance.
articles.lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — Beleaguered countries like Spain have been counting on a quick and neat way to fix their banks without taking on more crippling debt.

articles.headline: Earnings in United States Are Beginning to Feel a Pinch
articles.snippet: The estimated drop in corporate profits removes what had been an economic bright spot in an otherwise cloudy picture.
articles.abstract: The estimated drop in corporate profits removes what had been an economic bright spot in an otherwise cloudy picture.
articles.lead_paragraph: The boom in American corporate profits, which has far outpaced the gains in the broader economy since the end of the last recession, is faltering.

articles.headline: Dicey Path From App to Hit Show
articles.snippet: Despite millions of users, apps are not a surefire moneymaker for cautious studios.
articles.abstract: Despite millions of users, apps are not a surefire moneymaker for cautious studios.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Can smartphone apps become hit movies and television shows?

articles.headline: The Puppetry of Quotation Approval
articles.snippet: When quotations can be unilaterally taken back, the political Kabuki is all but complete.
articles.abstract: When quotations can be unilaterally taken back, the political Kabuki is all but complete.
articles.lead_paragraph: Now that it’s become clear that many journalists covering politics and government agree to quotation-approval as a condition of access, it’s tough not to see the pageant of democracy as just that: a carefully constructed performance meant to showcase the participants in the best light.

articles.headline: Despite a Slowdown, Smartphone Advances Are Still Ahead
articles.snippet: The iPhone 5 that Apple introduced last week with only incremental changes seemed to signal that the smartphone industry has entered an era of technological bunny hops.
articles.abstract: The iPhone 5 that Apple introduced last week with only incremental changes seemed to signal that the smartphone industry has entered an era of technological bunny hops.
articles.lead_paragraph: The arrival of the original iPhone in 2007 was a quantum leap for cellphones. Phones had never worked or looked like that.

articles.headline: On Web, a Fine Line on Free Speech Across the Globe
articles.snippet: As companies set their own rules legal experts say they must be flexible to strike the right balance between democratic values and law.
articles.abstract: As companies set their own rules legal experts say they must be flexible to strike the right balance between democratic values and law.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For Google last week, the decision was clear. An anti-Islamic video that provoked violence worldwide was not hate speech under its rules because it did not specifically incite violence against Muslims, even if it mocked their faith.

articles.headline: For a Fee, Streaming Local TV
articles.snippet: Aereo hopes to offer an alternative for viewers who prefer to grab their favorite shows piecemeal from a number of online sources.
articles.abstract: Aereo hopes to offer an alternative for viewers who prefer to grab their favorite shows piecemeal from a number of online sources.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the ninth floor of an old tire factory in Downtown Brooklyn, Joe Lipowski, chief technology officer of a company called Aereo, proudly showed off a steel sheet covered with TV antennas.

articles.headline: Cultural Clash Fuels Muslims Angry at Online Video
articles.snippet: In Egypt, some say that the protests at the American Embassy in Cairo and in about 20 countries over an anti-Islamic video was about more than religious sensitivity.
articles.abstract: In Egypt, some say that the protests at the American Embassy in Cairo and in about 20 countries over an anti-Islamic video was about more than religious sensitivity.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Stepping from the cloud of tear gas in front of the American Embassy here, Khaled Ali repeated the urgent question that he said justified last week’s violent protests at United States outposts around the Muslim world.

articles.headline: Looking, Very Closely, for Voter Fraud
articles.snippet: Busloads of illegal voters, cited by voter fraud groups like True the Vote, have yet to be seen. But that has not deterred such organizations, which widely support conservative causes.
articles.abstract: Busloads of illegal voters, cited by voter fraud groups like True the Vote, have yet to be seen. But that has not deterred such organizations, which widely support conservative causes.
articles.lead_paragraph: It might as well be Harry Potter’s invisible Knight Bus, because no one can prove it exists.

articles.headline: Trade Case May Produce Few Results
articles.snippet: The case against China on cars and auto parts will have little immediate impact, but it is one of the few legal options available.
articles.abstract: The case against China on cars and auto parts will have little immediate impact, but it is one of the few legal options available.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — President Obama’s trade case against China on cars and auto parts will have little immediate impact on jobs and companies in the United States, but it is one of the few legal options available to the United States as China’s auto industry faces overcapacity problems and looks overseas to increase sales.
